Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if local government grants have been paid in respect of certain houses in Dublin (details supplied).

A State grant of £275 was allocated in respect of each of these 12 houses and an instalment of £140 has been paid in each case. In the case of two of the houses the balance of £135 of the grant has been paid. In the remaining ten the balance of the grant has not yet been paid.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Furnished Lettings.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he will introduce regulations governing the letting of furnished rooms or flats.

Housing authorities are empowered under section 70 of the Housing Act, 1966, to make bye-laws setting minimum standards for rented accommodation. To assist the authorities in this task I circulated them with model bye-laws on the 28th June, 1973. A number of authorities have now indicated that they propose to adopt bye-laws based on the model while others have suggested amendments to it. These amendments are being considered by my Department at present.
I have been asked by Deputy Gogan to inquire if the Minister would direct that greater publicity be given to the circular. Apparently some people are not aware of their rights in this matter.

It is a matter for local authority members to ensure that this matter is dealt with. There is no point in telling the general public if local authority members are not prepared to support the efforts of the Government to deal with this matter in a fair way.

I understand the Coalition control most of the local authorities. I am not a member of any such authority. Would the Minister take the initiative to ensure that publicity is given to the rights of the individual, as the Department of Social Welfare are doing in connection with matters in their sphere?
From the replies we have received it appears that the local authorities concerned are aware of their responsibilities and are taking the necessary steps.
Individuals are not aware of this.
The local authorities will be bringing the matter to the notice of individuals.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Mortgage Interest Rates.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the progress he has made in discussions with building societies towards securing a reduction in the rate of interest on mortgages.

The interest rate charged by building societies on mortgages is determined by the rate which they must pay to investors to attract and retain funds. The present investment rate of 8 per cent tax paid would normally require a mortgage rate of 12½ per cent but the special subsidy introduced by the Government in May, 1973, enables the societies to keep the maximum rate charged on home loans at 11¼ per cent. I am glad to say that, subject to review, the Government have decided to continue the subsidy for a further period of six months from the 13th March. In the meantime, I will be keeping the matter under constant review in conjunction with the societies.

Will the Minister state if the Government have any proposals to restructure the building societies and to remove them from the competition of outside financial interests in relation to borrowing from their funds?

As the Deputy is aware, legislation is being prepared to up-date the law in relation to building societies. This will not have the immediate effect of dealing with the matter Deputy Timmons has in mind. So far as competition from outside financial houses is concerned, the Government are subsidising the building societies to the tune of 1 per cent in order to allow them to have some protection against other financial bodies.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Care of the Aged.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he will take steps to ensure that more dwellings are provided for elderly people.

As I told the Deputy in my reply to his Question No. 24 of 14th November, 1973, I asked housing authorities last October to initiate a new vigorous campaign for the care of the aged, jointly with health and welfare authorities. I suggested that the provision of suitable housing should be the focal point of this effort. Specifically, I asked that in each area an informal working party, representative of all the services involved should be set up to co-ordinate a new local campaign setting defined objectives; and that these objectives should include a planned programme for providing schemes of sheltered housing, and a formal system of community care and support for the elderly when they are rehoused. I have repeated this call publicly several times since then

As sufficient time has now elapsed since last October, I am asking housing authorities to report to me on the action taken since then to develop my suggested nationwide campaign. Apart from direct action by the local authorities, capital grants are payable by my Department to assist the provision of housing accommodation for the aged by religious and philanthropic bodies.
Can the Minister state if he has yet received any reports from the local authorities?
No, I have only recently asked for them.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - House Purchase Loans.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he is satisfied that the maximum income limit for house purchase loans is still adequate, in view of the recent rate of inflation.

The continuing growth in the number of applications for the loans indicates that the income limit—which I increased by more than 30 per cent last year— is still generally accepted as adequate. Applications with local authorities rose steadily from 7,854, value £20 million, at 31st December, 1972, to 14,319, value £46 million, at the end of last December. The rate of approvals has also increased remarkably—from 1,379 in the December, 1972 quarter to 3,352 in the three months ended 31st December last.
In the circumstances, I have no immediate intention of increasing the limit. However, I shall continue to keep the question under continuing review.
Would the Minister undertake a review every six months in view of the severe inflationary rate?
I am keeping the matter under continual review. I made two changes in a short period last year.
I am not trying to take from what the Minister has done in this matter.
In view of the recent wage agreement, would the Minister consider tying them to that?
Most of the people looking for this kind of loan will be under the limit——
There are some people on the borderline who would not qualify. Will the Minister take into consideration the new wage agreement?
The last arrangement made by me included practically everyone in the lower middle income group. I should prefer to let it run for a few more months.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Water and Sewerage Schemes.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the number of group water schemes in County Cork which will qualify for grants from FEOGA; and the number of applications for grants for such schemes being processed at present.

Applications were made by my Department in June, 1973 for FEOGA aid towards the provision of six group water supply schemes in County Cork. All these applications are currently being processed by the EEC Commission.
Is it not a fact that this will take some time? I do not think the Minister has any control over these applications.

We have no control. The matter should not take too long. Receipt of the applications for FEOGA aid was formally acknowledged by the EEC Commission on 18th July and the groups concerned were immediately notified by the Department. We are reminding them fairly frequently that we would like an early decision.
asked the Minister for Local Government when he will sanction the Croghan No. 1 regional water scheme which has been submitted to him for approval by Roscommon County Council.
As far as my Department are aware this scheme has not been accorded a high priority by the local authority.
It is primarily for the local authority to consider whether in the current circumstances of the area and the other priority needs in the county there is an urgent need for any part of the scheme.
I understand that the county council are at present considering the preparation of revised proposals for this scheme.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: Deputy Kitt has requested a written reply to Question No. 72.
asked the Minister for Local Government when the Inistioge sewerage scheme, County Kilkenny will be sanctioned.
I approved the revised preliminary proposals for this scheme on the 7th February, 1974.
asked the Minister for Local Government the position regarding payment of the final grants to the trustees of the Clanleigh/ Kilmagoura group water scheme, County Cork.

Ten grants were paid on 30th January, 1974, bringing the total number of grants paid to date to 45. The payment of the remaining nine grants will be arranged when all work outstanding has been completed.
asked the Minister for Local Government if his Department have received proposals to extend Donoughmore water scheme, County Cork; and, if so, when he will sanction them.
Proposals for this extension are under consideration in my Department.

On the basis of the information available to me however, it does not appear that the local authority regard the scheme as having a high priority in their overall programme of water and sewerage schemes in planning.

asked the Minister for Local Government the action it is now proposed to take as a result of the survey carried out on local authority sewerage systems in order to reduce pollution; and the amount of money that will be made available for the coming year.

I would refer the Deputy to Appendix 9 of the Report of the Inter-Departmental Working Group on Water Pollution which sets out the result of a survey of local authority sewerage systems and indicates the remedial works being undertaken or planned in each area. The information at Appendix 9 makes it clear that local authorities generally are aware of their responsibilities in this matter.

MainHeading.P: The increase in the capital provision for sanitary services from £8.23 million in 1972-73 to £12.95 million in 1973-74 is encouraging and enabling local authorities to accelerate their sanitary services programmes generally, including anti-pollution works. I cannot tell the Deputy at this stage the amount of money that will be provided for the programmes in the coming year.

Speaker.P: I understood from the Minister when I raised this question before that he was proposing to introduce legislation as a result of this report. Has he made any progress?
The legislation is well advanced and it should be possible to introduce it shortly.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Window Replacement Grants.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he will consider amending the regulations to allow grants for replacement windows to be made separately from reconstruction grants normally available to people after 15 years' residence in a house.

The limiting period of 15 years does not apply to further grants for the replacement of windows where the work is necessary because of damage caused by wind, rain or flooding or events outside the control of the applicant.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Tralee Sports Complex.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he will indicate the grant that will be given to Tralee Sports Complex, County Kerry in respect of a swimming pool.

I have santioned the raising of a loan of £80,000 by Tralee Urban District Council for construction of a swimming pool which will form part of a proposed community sports complex in Tralee. Subsidy at the rate of 50 per cent of the loan charges arising on this loan will be paid by my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Community Centres.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he proposes to make grants available for community centres in the coming year; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

The amenity grants scheme provides grants for works of general amenity including community centres. No indication can be given at this stage as to the provision to be made for the scheme in the coming year.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Undesirable Risks Committee.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the decision, if any, that has been reached by the Undesirable Risks Committee in the case of a person (name supplied) in County Tipperary; and if he is aware of the financial loss suffered by this person due to the refusal of the insurance companies to insure him.

The decision of the Undesirable Risks Committee on this case was not accepted by the insurance company concerned. There is no way in which I can ensure that a company will offer cover in any particular instance. I brought the hardship involved in the case to the attention of the committee and I understand that an offer of cover is now possible. I have conveyed this to the person concerned.
Does that offer cover buses, cars and tractors and does the Minister consider the offer a reasonable one?
I am sorry I do not have that information. There is a section of the Department which deals with this and there are little things that happen of which I am not aware. I am afraid this is one of them.
Have this committee any control at all over insurance companies?
The committee have not. This matter was first brought to my notice by Deputy Brendan Griffin——
I rather thought the Minister would get that one in.

——and he has been pressing the matter since. He could, as a matter of fact, give the same information to the Deputy that I have given him because Deputy Griffin has had this information for over a week now.

A Leas-Cheann Chomhairle, would you control the Minister? I asked a very simple question. What is the function of this committee if they cannot solve cases? There is no point in having a committee if the insurance companies ignore them. This is getting to be a very serious position with a 25 per cent increase in the Dublin area.

The position is that the committee cannot insist on insurance companies paying but they have been reasonably successful in many cases, including this one. While it is not the ideal way to deal with matters like this the members of the committee are doing a reasonably good job and we should not knock them in the way in which they are being knocked by Deputy Davern.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Dublin Redevelopment.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the present position regarding the proposed redevelopment of Hollyfield and Mount Pleasant Buildings, Dublin.

The administration of their housing estate is primarily the responsibility of Dublin Corporation. I understand, however, that in Hollyfield Buildings two blocks comprising single rooms have been demolished and the site has been surfaced for a play area. The four remaining blocks comprise self-contained flats and provide accommodation for 47 families. The question of redevelopment of these buildings in conjunction with some adjoining property is being examined by the corporation.

MainHeading.P: As regards Mount Pleasant Buildings, two blocks comprising single rooms have also been demolished and the site used as a play area. The five remaining blocks comprise self-contained flats and provide accommodation for approximately 150 families. In view of the demand for housing in the city area the corporation do not propose to demolish these buildings but to lower the density of occupation and to improve and repair them as far as possible.

Speaker.P: Will the original proposals the corporation had some years ago to develop these two sites be continued in the same way as St. Michael's in Inchicore was developed?
I have given a full reply to the Deputy and I have nothing to add.
There were proposals and I am trying to find out if there are any changes.

I have not got the original proposals here but the Deputy will be aware from what I have already told him that in Hollyfield Buildings two blocks comprising single rooms have been demolished and the site has been surfaced for a play area; the four remaining blocks comprise self-contained flats and provide accommodation for 47 families. The question of redevelopment of these buildings in conjunction with some adjoining property is being examined by the corporation. In the second case there are approximately 150 families in the five remaining blocks and the city commissioners do not propose to demolish these buildings; they propose to lower the density of occupation and improve and repair the buildings as far as possible. This would be in line with the request I made to local authorities to try to maintain existing housing stock where it can be either maintained or repaired.

The Minister must be aware that in Islandbridge, St. Michael's estate, and so forth, development has been most successful and the accommodation is much sought after. We would like to see the same thing happening in Rathmines.
asked the Minister for Local Government the present position regarding the proposed redevelopment of Moore Street/ Parnell Street, Dublin.

As I indicated in reply to a previous question from the Deputy this is a matter for Dublin Corporation. I understand that tenders submitted for the carrying out of phase I of the redevelopment project are at present being examined by the corporation and that it is hoped to make a decision shortly.
Will this development take place as a result of imported money by multi-national investment companies?
That is a separate question and I could not answer the Deputy.
I was just wondering what proportion of Irish capital would be invested and what proportion of non-national capital.
I suggest the Deputy take the matter up with his colleagues in the corporation.
I am not a member of the corporation.
But he surely has somebody on the corporation who will look after it for him.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Environment Policies.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the steps the Government have taken to comply with the Stockholm recommendation for an international convention to include representative samples of all ecosystems which have scientific value of international significance and in particular which contain genetic resources which it is important to conserve as well as threatened animal and plant species and their habitats.
It has not been possible to identify the recommendation to which the Deputy's question relates.

MainHeading.P: As the Deputy may be aware a special environment programme is now being prepared by the UN following the Stockholm Conference on the Human Environment. I would expect that the recommendations for international action made at the conference—and they were many—will be the subject of initiatives under that programme as may be appropriate. Any initiatives of that kind that may be of concern to my Department will be considered in due course.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if the Government will review its policies on the environment before the next UN conference on this subject; if it is proposed to contribute to an environmental fund or financial institution to deal with special problems of the human environment; and, if so, the amount of the contribution.

Environmental policy is under continuous review. In regard to the question of a contribution to the UN Environment Fund I would refer to information given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 13 November, 1973, in reply to questions by the Deputy in the matter.
The one thing missing in that reply is information on the size of the contribution this country might make.
I suggest the Deputy looks up the reply given to him by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 13th November.
The Minister would have it in his brief.
I probably have but it is in the Official Report anyway.
The Minister has a staff to do the work for him. I have to do it myself.
The Deputy does it pretty well.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Bomb Damage Compensation.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government whether it is proposed to introduce legislation which would relieve Monaghan County Council from liability for claims for damage to property arising from bomb attacks in Clones, County Monaghan; and, if so, when.

I would refer the Deputy to the statement made by the Minister for Finance in the Seanad on the 20th February, 1974, (column 203 of volume 77) when speaking on the Exchequer and Local Financial Years Bill, 1973.

There is a figure for bomb damage in Clones of £388,000 and the victims of that bombing have had to procure loans at an interest rate of 14 per cent. Would the Minister not agree that the Government should take immediate action?

First of all, I should like to point out to the Deputy that ministerial responsibility under the malicious inquiry code rests with the Minister for Justice. If it will help the Deputy I will quote for him what the Minister for Finance said in the Seanad on 20th February.

On the point raised by Senator Dolan, the Government have already given an assurance that any bomb damage in border counties arising out of the unhappy disturbances in the North of Ireland will not become a charge on local rates.
I would ask Deputy Leonard to leave it at that because that is as definite as it could be from the Minister for Finance.
Does the Minister not realise that if people have to pay 14 per cent interest for three years that it will be almost 50 per cent of the cost——

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: That is a separate question.

Is the Minister also aware that prior to the general election in February, 1973, the leaders of the Fine Gael and Labour Parties gave an assurance to the Monaghan County Council that they would foot the Bill for bomb damage?

The damage did not occur at that time Deputy Leonard is out of line with his comments. There was no bomb damage before the general election such as he is referring to now. The commitments he is talking about were not given.
I would take the Minister up on that point.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: We must not have an argument at Question Time.
I would ask the Minister to check back on his dates.
If there was bomb damage before the last general election perhaps Deputy Leonard or Deputy Colley would like to tell me why the previous Government did nothing about it.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: We cannot have arguments at Question Time. Question No. 86 is postponed. Question No. 87.
Will the Coalition leaders honour that assurance?
The Minister has made a statement. Is he withdrawing it or not? Is he saying that there was no bomb damage in Clones before the last general election? Is he bluffing as usual?
I am not interested in whether Deputy Colley scores a political point.
I am concerned with the truth.
So far as I am concerned truth does not come into this because I will tell the truth. If the bomb damage was there before the last election Fianna Fáil did nothing about it——
Is the Minister aware that the bomb damage in Clones in 1972——
Question No. 86 postponed.
Deputy Ryan, Minister for Finance, gave an assurance to the Senate, and this was more than Fianna Fáil did.
Arising further from the Minister's reply——

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: There can be no further supplementary questions. I am calling question No. 87.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Bog Roads Construction.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he will provide sufficient finance through a special vote for the repair of bog roads or authorise the local authorities to use as much of the local improvement scheme funds as is necessary for this purpose, to eliminate the necessity to complete application forms in respect of such roads.

The only funds available for the improvement of bog roads which are not public roads are those provided under the local improvements scheme. Under this scheme county councils have discretion within their allocation as to the amount to be expended on bog road schemes. As councils undertake works as agents of the land holders it is not possible to dispense with forms of application as requested in the question.

Would the Minister not agree that because of the urgency this year of producing extra fuel, it would be almost impossible to work the local improvement schemes under the circumstances? The Minister will appreciate that names must be collected and agreement reached by the people concerned in order to work these schemes and it will not be possible to have this done before the turf season comes.
Why would it not be possible?
I am sure the Minister must be aware of the difficulty and time it takes to collect names and have them processed and get the people to make their contributions.

I live in the country close to a bog. If people are interested there will be no difficulty in getting the information. One evening should be sufficient to collect this information. After that if somebody is interested enough, it will be looked after.

Will the Minister agree that the people who own the bogs may not be using them? They are the people who will have to sign for the local improvement schemes and give permission. The people who are using the bogs will not have the authority to sign the forms. In view of this, I would urge the Minister to have a re-think about this and make money available to county councils to develop the bog roads before the turf season.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Dublin Reconstruction Grants.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the reason for the delay in allocating a reconstruction grant to a person in Crumlin, Dublin (details supplied); and if such a grant will be allocated in this case.

This application is being considered under the provisions relating to the payment of grants where a previous grant has been paid within the preceding 15 years. Such grants are available for works occasioned by something outside the control of the applicant which are urgently necessary for the conservation of the house. Since the works in question were completed before my Department's inspector called to the house the county council were asked for a report on the condition of the house prior to the commencement of work. They recently confirmed that the work carried out was necessary and I am therefore accepting it for grant purposes. My Department's inspector has been asked to prepare the necessary grant allocation.

asked the Minister for Local Government the reason for the delay in allocating a reconstruction grant to a person in Blanchardstown, County Dublin (details supplied); and if a grant will be allocated in this case.

My Department's inspector called to this house on 20th February but the applicant's wife did not wish to have the inspection carried out at that time. Arrangements have been made to have the house inspected this week.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Road Safety Association.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the progress that has been made in setting up a national road safety association.

I established the Road Safety Association on the 16th July, 1973. From the date of its inauguration the association have assumed functions in relation to road safety propaganda and education formerly being carried out by my Department. In addition to carrying out the programme of road safety promotion taken over from my Department, the association are at present engaged in finalising details of their programme for 1974-75 and in formulating future road safety policy. I expect to be in a position very shortly to make the order confering corporate status on the association.
Is it true that the proper staffing of this association from the Civil Service is being held up in the Department of the Public Services?
That is not true.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Car Tax Office.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he will provide a car tax office on the south side of Dublin.
The opening of a second motor taxation office in the Dublin area is a matter for decision by the licensing authority in the first instance.
Were there any proposals to establish such an office in Dundrum and, if so, would the Minister approve it?
No proposals have come to me. This would be a matter for the corporation concerned.
Might I suggest to the Minister that he checks with his officials to find out if such proposals have been made?

I am sure there have not been because there is no such information in my brief. Last year Dublin County Council advocated opening an office in the Town Hall in Dún Laoghaire. Is that what the Deputy is talking about?

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: Question No. 92.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Dublin Traffic Proposals.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he will indicate the proposals for one-way traffic at Mount Pleasant Square, Dublin.

The initiation and implementation of proposals to provide for one-way traffic on streets in the Dublin city area is entirely within the competence of the Garda Commissioner and the Dublin Corporation. As such proposals are not notified to my Department, I have no information on any measures that may be under consideration for the location in question.
Does the Minister have to approve of proposals of this kind?
I am not informed of them. This is a matter for Dublin Corporation and the Garda authorties.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Dublin Speed Limit.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government when the speed limit of 40 mph in operation on the extra-wide dual carriage-way between Long Mile Road and Newlands Cross, Dublin will be revised.

The question as to whether the speed limit of 40 mph on this new section of dual carriageway should be revised is being considered in the course of a review of speed limits in Dublin city and county which is nearing finalisation.

The Minister has been giving me the same reply on his Estimate and to other questions. The signs for 40 miles an hour are still there on the widest dual carriageway in the country. If the local authority will do nothing about it why will the Minister not do something?
Even on very wide roads accidents have been occurring very frequently.
On this stretch?
I am not very anxious to rush into giving a licence to drive more quickly.
There are six and eight lines of traffic travelling on this carriageway.
So what! Accidents occur there just as frequently as anywhere else.
When approximately will this review be completed?
I have been informed that it is nearing completion. I imagine that I will have some definite information within a month.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Mayo Bridge.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he will make funds available to construct a bridge to Uggool village, Bellacorrick, County Mayo.
Funds are available to Mayo County Council under the local improvements scheme for works of this nature. It is a matter for that council to decide whether or not to undertake the project.

Is the Minister aware that the sum of money provided for local improvement schemes has averaged about £100,000 per year and, when that is spread over the whole county, it is not sufficient to do the existing work? There has been a footbridge in this village for the past 32 years and that is the only access people have. Is it not about time we had some scheme to improve facilities for people living in such conditions?

This is a matter for the county council. The county council have decided not to undertake the provision of a new bridge to take cars in place of the footbridge. The council consider that the cost, an estimated £3,500, is too high to be undertaken under the local improvement schemes. They propose to improve the road at a cost of £1,700, starting in May of this year. The responsibility for the administration of the local improvement schemes rests entirely with the county council. I am sorry but there is nothing I can do about it.

I am sure the Minister is aware that the county council have applications far in excess of the amount of money which is available to do the ordinary schemes in the county. This is a special scheme and special funds would be necessary for it.

I agree that there was a backlog of 620 rural improvement schemes in Mayo at the end of September last. I can assure Deputy Gallagher that there is hardly a county in Ireland that has not made special representations from time to time. They all consider that the scheme in their area is of special importance. I am sorry but there is nothing I can do about it.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Dublin Corporation Capital Works Programme.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he is aware that Dublin Corporation has had to arrange overdraft accommodation to the extent of £1 million to facilitate the implementation of its capital works programme without interruption, pending payments due from the Local Loans Fund; and by how much the interest rate will affect the rates.

I am not so aware. Dublin Corporation have applied for an authorisation to borrow up to £750,000 by means of temporary overdraft on their capital account during the six-month period up to 30th September next. This amount is exactly the same as that submitted by the corporation and sanctioned by successive Ministers for Local Government for the corresponding period since 1961. At present, there is no undue delay in making issues from the Local Loans Fund.

There is no information in my Department on the final part of the question. I understand, however, that it is anticipated that the cost of any overdraft facilities used will be offset by interest accruing to the corporation on foot of periodic credit balances on their accounts.
Since the question was put down there have been reports that the new drainage schemes will run into a great deal of extra financial cost. Will this involve a charge on the rates?

The reply which I have given to Deputy Lemass is as of today, 21st March. It is up to date. Obviously, Deputy Lemass got wrong information before he put down the question and I do not think that his extra information is any more accurate.
If we see newspaper reports which concern us, is it not proper for us to raise the matter in the House?
By way of question, yes.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: This is Question Time.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Camac River Culverting.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government when the culverting of the Camac River, Dublin, will take place.
There are no proposals before my Department for the culverting of the Camac River.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Planning Appeals.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the number of occasions on which costs were awarded to or against parties involved in planning appeals in the last 12 months.
The answer is none.
asked the Minister for Local Government the number of planning appeals which could be classed as vexatious or frivolous lodged with him during the past 12 months.
No record has been kept of the number of such appeals during the past 12 months.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Planning Exemption Certificates.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government whether he will direct county councils to issue certificates of exemption from planning permission requirements, for Department of Agriculture and Fisheries grant purposes, in the case of pig fattening stations or large sow units.

The Local Government (Planning and Development) Act, 1963, and the regulations made thereunder do not provide for the issue of certificates of exemption from planning permission. A person may carry out exempted development without approaching the planning authority. If in doubt he should consult with the planning authority. Any question as to what in any particular case is or is not development or exempted development may be referred to me under section 5 of the 1963 Act for decision.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Use of Diesel.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if he will investigate why a man (name supplied) was summonsed for using red-coloured diesel in a cut-down landrover which was licensed at £2.50 agricultural rate; and if he will make a general statement on this matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. R. Ryan) Richie Ryan
Speaker.P: The person named has not been prosecuted in the circumstances outlined by the Deputy. His son was, however, twice prosecuted in similar circumstances and I am assuming that it is to this that the Deputy is referring. The summonses related to the unauthorised use of rebated hydrocarbon oil. If the landrover involved had been so modified as to entitle it to be regarded as an agricultural tractor, the use of rebated oil would have been permissible. Such, however, was not the case and convictions were recorded in respect of offences committed on 21st November, 1972, and 12th June, 1973.

The person concerned produced a letter to me from the licensing authority in Cork County Council stating that this landrover had passed their inspection and been taxed at £2.50 in 1972. He is appealing to the Minister to use his influence with regard to this fine.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The Deputy will appreciate that it is not open to the Minister for Finance to exercise influence in a field which is the responsibility of the Revenue Commissioners on the one hand and the courts on the other. The court took the view in these two cases that the conditions which would have exempted this use had not been fulfilled.
They had this assurance from the licensing authority in Cork County Council. Could they take it up again with the Revenue Commissioners because there is grave dissatisfaction in this case?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: It would appear to be a matter for the local authority concerned. The court has issued its findings regarding the decision of the local authority.
The court is not in line with the decision of the local authority. This is the problem at the moment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: I appreciate that it is a problem but it is not open to the Minister for Finance to do anything about it.
Is there a conflict between the local authority and the court's finding?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The court has taken a different view from that apparently taken by the local authority in the first instance.
Would the Minister not agree that in circumstances like that there is a very strong case for the Revenue Commissioners to exercise the discretion vested in them?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: I am sure the Revenue Commissioners have given and will give this case appropriate consideration.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Health Expenses Tax Remission.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if tax remission will be allowed on health expenses in excess of £37.50 in the context of a nine-month budget.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The Exchequer and Local Financial Years Act, 1974, recently enacted, provides for a change of Exchequer and local financial years to a calendar year basis as from 1st January, 1975, with a transitional nine-months' financial period from 1st April, 1974, to 31st December, 1974. The Act does not, however, change the income tax year so that the next income tax year will be the 12-months' period from 6th April, 1974, to 5th April, 1975, and not the nine-months' period ending on 31st December, 1974. In the circumstances, the adjustment of tax allowances and reliefs to a nine-months' basis will not arise.

Will there be any period in which a full 12 months exemption from tax under this head will not occur, where there will be a nine months transitional period? Surely there has to be some transitional period?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Until such time as the tax year is changed the adjustment which the Deputy has in mind will not arise. For reasons which I explained during the course of the debate on the Exchequer and Local Financial Years Bill, it is not proposed to make a change in the tax year as distinct from the financial year for the time being.
Therefore, the forthcoming budget on 3rd April will be a 12 months budget and the other one will come in before it has expired?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The financial year will be for nine months and tax will continue to be levied on a 12 months basis.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Capital Gains Tax

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if winners of large prizes in lotteries, including the Irish Sweepstakes, will be liable in future to a form of capital gains tax.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The White Paper on Capital Taxation issued on 28th February, 1974, was intended to give an outline of the Government's proposals in regard to capital taxation. I would refer the Deputy to paragraph 90 (a) of the White Paper which proposes that winnings from lotteries and sweepstakes in excess of £15,000 a year would be liable to capital gains tax. Paragraph 87 of the same Paper indicates that a non-resident would not be liable in respect of any such winnings. The White Paper invites representations and suggestions from the public in regard to the proposals contained in it and I would like to emphasise that I will be happy to receive views from interested persons and organisations.
Would the Minister not agree that in view of the good work which this sweepstake is doing it should be an exempted capital gains heading?

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: That is a separate question.
It is a direct question. It is a question as to whether or not we will help the sweepstake.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The Deputy will appreciate that if the winner of a sweepstake prize died that prize would form part of the estate and would be subject to estate duty which is a capital taxation.
One would expect that a person who won the sweepstake would start living.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The shock might kill some of them.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Science and Technology Policy.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance the present position regarding the Government's policy relating to science and technology.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The Government's policy is to secure the optimum contribution from scientific and technological activity towards economic and social development and the attainment of national goals. A review of such activity directed towards this end and undertaken with the collaboration of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development will be completed shortly, following which I hope to put in train the necessary legislative measures for the introduction of new institutional arrangements for the formulation and implementation of a fully integrated national policy for science and technology.
Could the Minister indicate when we might have the announcement?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Sooner than later.
Whatever that means.
It is even more vague than some of the answers we get.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Space Exploration.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if the Government are satisfied with the scale and scope of this country's contribution to Europe's co-operative efforts to explore and exploit space for peaceful purposes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Ireland has had observer status in the European Space Research Organisation for a number of years. This body has been very successful in promoting co-ordination of the efforts of West European countries to draw benefit from space research. The question of our joining as full members of this organisation, or of the European Space Agency (ESA) which will be its successor body from 1st March next, is currently under consideration. Because of the considerable expenditure which would be involved, a close analysis is being made of possible benefits as against estimated costs. Apart from the question of joining the European Space Research Organisation, consideration is also being given to Ireland's becoming a member of the European Space Conference.
The remaining questions will appear on next Tuesday's Order Paper.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Galway Water Scheme.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if his Department has yet agreed to the proposed extensions to the Caltra-Castleblakeney-Ballymacward group water supply scheme, County Galway; and, if so, if he will indicate when work may be expected to commence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: My Department's supervising inspector for County Galway recently visited the area and discussed the proposed extensions with representatives of the Castleblakeney-Ballymacward group. He arranged that the design engineer engaged by the group would furnish plans covering the precise areas covered by the proposed extensions. When these plans are received they will be examined jointly by my inspectors and Galway County Council's liaison officer for group schemes to confirm whether all, or any, of the extensions are technically feasible.
In the circumstances it is not possible at this stage to indicate if and when work may commence on the proposed extensions.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Charolais-Fleckvieh Cross Bulls.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if he is satisfied that all Charolais cross and Fleckvieh cross bulls in respect of which licences were issued in 1973 were used only in suckler herds of more than 20 females; if he has received any reports on the quality of the progeny of such bulls; and if the quality justifies the continuance of the scheme.

asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries the number of (a) Charolais cross bulls and (b) Fleckvieh cross bulls in respect of which licences were issued in 1973; and if he has revoked or proposes to revoke any of those licences during the coming year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Clinton) Mark A. Clinton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Clinton)
Speaker.P: With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 215 and 216 together.

Licences were issued in 1973 for 331 Charolais-cross and 50 Fleckviehcross bulls. The licences are issued only to applicants who have declared that they are the owners of suckler herds containing at least 20 breeding females and the bulls may be used only in these herds.
